TRANSLATION INVARIANT FILTERS
AND VAN DER WAERDENS THEOREM
MAURO DI NASSO
Abstract. We present a self-contained proof of a strong version of van der
Waerdens Theorem. By using translation invariant lters that are maximal
with respect to inclusion, a simple inductive argument shows the existence of
piecewise syndetically-many monochromatic arithmetic progressions of any
length k in every nite coloring of the natural numbers. All the constructions
presented are constructive in nature, in the sense that the involved maximal
lters are dened by recurrence on suitable countable algebras of sets. No use
of the axiom of choice or of Zorns Lemma is needed.
Introduction
The importance of maximal objects in mathematics is well-known, starting from
the fundamental examples of maximal ideals in algebra, and of ultralters in certain
areas of topology and of Ramsey theory. In this paper we focus on maximal lters
on suitable countable algebras of sets which are stable under translations. By using
such maximal objects, along with ultralters extending it, we give a proof of a
strong version of the following classical result in Ramsey theory:
Theorem (van der Waerden - 1927) In every nite partition N = C1  . . .  Cr
there exists a piece C = Ci that contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions,
that is, for every k there exists a progression x + y, x + 2y, . . . , x + ky  C.
In fact, we will prove the existence of piecewise syndetically-many monochro-
matic arithmetic progressions of any length k.
Usually, van der Waerdens Theorem is proved either by double induction using
elaborated, but elementary, combinatorial arguments in the style of the original
proof [5], or by using properties of the smallest ideal K(N, ) in the algebra of
ultralters (see [4, Ch.14]; see also [2, 1] for stronger versions). In our proof, for
any given piecewise set, we restrict to a suitable countable algebra of sets, and
explicitly construct by recursion a maximal translation invariant lter, and then
an ultralter extending it. The desired result is nally obtained by a short proof
by induction, that is essentially a simplied version of an argument that was used
in [3] in the framework of the compact right-topological semigroup (N, ). It is
worth remarking that, contrarily to the usual ultralter proof, we make no explicit
use of the algebra in the space of ultralters; in fact, we make no use of the axiom
of choice nor of Zorns Lemma.
